security_audit.summary: The static analysis findings are overwhelmingly false positives. The 'weak cryptographic algorithm' alerts are triggered by color hex codes (e.g., #E69F00) being misidentified as hashes. The 'external commands' findings are code examples in documentation, not actual command execution. The 'certificate/key files' findings are also false positives - no actual cryptographic materials are present. This is a legitimate scientific visualization library with no security risks.

content.value_statement: Scientific visualization transforms data into clear, accurate figures for publication. This skill ensures your figures meet journal standards while being accessible to all readers, including those with color blindness.
actual_capabilities: Generate publication-ready figures with proper DPI and formats
Apply journal-specific styling (Nature, Science, Cell, PLOS)
Create multi-panel figures with consistent styling
Export figures in vector (PDF/EPS) and raster (TIFF/PNG) formats
Add statistical annotations and error bars correctly
limitations: Requires matplotlib, seaborn, and plotly installations
Focused on 2D scientific plots, not 3D visualizations
Designed for static figures, not interactive web plots
Journal specifications may change over time

prompt_templates.title: Basic Publication Plot
prompt_templates.scenario: Create a simple line plot for a paper
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a publication-quality line plot of my data with error bars, proper labels with units, and save as PDF. Use the Okabe-Ito color palette for accessibility.

prompt_templates.title: Multi-Panel Figure
prompt_templates.scenario: Combine multiple plots into one figure
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a 4-panel figure (2x2 layout) comparing different experimental conditions. Label panels A-D, use consistent styling, and ensure the figure fits Nature's single column width.

prompt_templates.title: Statistical Comparison
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a box plot comparing three treatment groups with individual data points overlaid. Add significance markers and use colorblind-safe colors. Include sample sizes.

prompt_templates.title: Journal-Specific Formatting
prompt_templates.prompt: Configure matplotlib for Cell journal requirements and create a heatmap with proper colormap. Ensure the figure meets their dimension and font requirements.

output_examples.input: Create a publication-ready bar chart comparing control vs treatment groups with error bars
output: Applied Nature journal styling with 85mm single-column width
Used Okabe-Ito colorblind-safe palette (orange #E69F00 for control, blue #0072B2 for treatment)
Added error bars showing 95% confidence intervals
Set font to Arial 8pt for labels, 6pt for tick labels
Saved as both PDF (vector) and PNG (300 DPI) formats
Figure includes individual data points with jitter for transparency

best_practices: Always test figures in grayscale to ensure accessibility
Include sample sizes (n) and error bar definitions in captions
Use vector formats (PDF/EPS) for plots, raster (TIFF) only for images
anti_patterns: Never use JPEG format for scientific figures - it creates compression artifacts
Avoid red-green color combinations that are invisible to 8% of men
Don't use 3D effects or unnecessary decorations that distort data perception

faq.question: What file format should I use for my figures?
faq.answer: Use vector formats (PDF or EPS) for plots and graphs. Use TIFF or PNG for microscopy images or photographs. Never use JPEG for scientific figures.

faq.question: How do I ensure my figures are colorblind-friendly?
faq.answer: Use the built-in Okabe-Ito palette, test figures in grayscale, and add redundant encoding like different line styles or markers.

faq.question: What's the minimum font size for publication figures?
faq.answer: At final print size, use minimum 7-9 pt for axis labels and 6-8 pt for tick labels. Sans-serif fonts like Arial work best.

faq.question: How do I create multi-panel figures?
faq.answer: Use matplotlib's GridSpec for flexible layouts, label panels with bold letters (A, B, C), and ensure consistent styling across all panels.

faq.question: Can I use this for any journal?
faq.answer: Yes, the skill includes configurations for Nature, Science, Cell, PLOS, ACS, and IEEE. You can also use custom dimensions for other journals.

faq.question: What statistical information should I include?
faq.answer: Always show error bars (specify SD, SEM, or CI in caption), include sample sizes (n), and mark statistical significance clearly.
